content.webTitle: US makes case at United Nations for cooperative effort to fight Isis – as it happened

fields.headline: US makes case at United Nations for cooperative effort to fight Isis – as it happened
fields.bodyText: We’re going to wrap up our live blog coverage for the day. Here’s a summary of where things stand: The United States sought – and won – vocal international support for its new military offensive against Isis, as the United Nations general assembly convened. The centerpiece of the American suasion effort was an address in which President Barack Obama called on nations to join “a broad coalition to dismantle this network of death.” British prime minister David Cameron supported military action. “We need to act, and we need to act now,” he said. Parliament was recalled to meet Friday to discuss the issue. Holland said it was sending jets to fight Isis. Jordan and Turkey vowed to support the cause, as did France. Saudi Arabia and the UAE were named as participants in US-led airstrikes in Syria late Wednesday. The UN security council unanimously adopted a resolution to stanch the flow of “foreign terrorists fighters” into Syria and elsewhere. Late Wednesday afternoon, the Pentagon announced new strikes on oil facilities in Syria which they said netted Isis up to $2m a day. It was the third day of strikes in Syria. The Pentagon said it was still investigating whether US strikes in Syria on Tuesday killed a leader of the al Qaeda-linked Khorasan group. Violence in Iraq continued. Around 200 Iraqi soldiers were said to be trapped by Isis fighters in an army camp south of Ramadi in western Iraq. Isis was said to have reinforced fighters who are battling Kurdish forces for control of the town on Kobani close to the Turkish border. Isis militants killed at least 19 members of a Shia militia in an ambush attack outside Baghdad, Iraqi police said. A Syrian opposition group affiliated with the “moderate” Free Syrian Army condemned the US-led air strikes in a new video. An Algerian group claiming ties to Isis beheaded a French hostage, a tourist who was captured Sunday. Read the previous blog summary. Pentagon spokesman Navy Rear Adm. John Kirby told CNN that U.S. and coalition forces hit 12 targets, including oil refineries that were providing up to $2 million a day in income to the Islamic State group, AP reports. As of Tuesday, according to U.S. Central Command, the U.S. had conducted airstrikes that hit at least 20 locations in Syria. Combat aircraft flew 64 sorties. “International partners” (via CNN): ABC News says the strikes are over: At the UN, John Kerry says he has to go and hands the security council chair to ambassador Samantha Power. Here’s hoping she has her afternoon free. Pentagon spokesman Rear Adm. John Kirby releases a statement confirming the new air strikes in Syria Wednesday. Via AFP: “I can confirm that US military and Arab partner forces are undertaking additional strikes today against ISIL (Islamic State group) terrorists in Syria,” press secretary Rear Admiral John Kirby said in a statement. “These operations are ongoing so we will not provide additional details at this time.” Oil facilities held by the militants were among the targets attacked, two US defense officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told AFP. Syria Deeply has quoted analysts saying Isis makes up to $3m a day selling oil. Earlier today the Iraqi prime minister asked the American president for more weapons, explaining that Isis militants had been stripping the Iraqi army. That is still happening, reports the Washington Post. Saqlawiyah is near Fallujah west of Baghdad. Obama leaves the security council meeting to speak at “another UN forum.” He hands off to US secretary of state John Kerry. “I will note that it is very rare that the UN achieves the kind of consensus that we see represented in this resolution,” he says. The agreement shows, he says, that “The brand of violent, extreme terrorism [of Isil] is something that must be rejected by all of us in the civilized world.” “In our fight against terrorism, all actions that our national interest necessitates will be taken,” Erdogan says. He says Turkey hosts 1.3m Syrian refugees and last week alone 140,000 Kurds entered Turkey. “We have not received the kind of support we’ve been looking for from the international community” he says. Erdogan says Turkey has been “target of unjust criticism in this context”. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan is next at the UN security council. He says Turkey has been warning the international community about the terrorist threat. “The spread of Isil’s threat towards Iraq is a result of conditions on the ground and is a result of sectarian policies of the former government,” he says. “Turkey has been taking a leading role... working to prevent the flow of foreign fighters into the region for a long time.” He says the flow starts at original countries “and for a long time we have been calling on the countries concerned to cooperate with us on this issue.” “We finally witnessed an increased share of information from” origin countries, he says. Erdogan says there are now 6,300 individuals on a no-entry list; close to 1,000 foreigners deported; instituted risk analysis group at airports. Roughly simultaneous with the announcement of renewed strikes against Isis, Iraqi prime minister Haider al-Abadi was invited to address the security council: Reuters snap: PENTAGON CONFIRMS STRIKES UNDERWAY, SAYS WILL PROVIDE DETAILS AS “OPERATIONALLY APPROPRIATE” AFP adds: Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi is next. He says China backs the UN resolution against “foreign terrorist fighters”. He expresses condolences to France for the killing of tourist Hervé Gourdel in Algeria. “We must stay alert” against the terrorism threat, he says. “We would be prepared to cooperate on an equitable bases,” Lavrov says, beginning with an honest assessment, he says, of the real source of the problem we’re trying to solve. Lavrov says the invasion of Iraq, bombing of Libya and arming of the Syrian opposition has greatly exacerbated the problem of foreign fighters. Not the same sources of the problem the United States would likely name. Lavrov says Isis is not the only source of terrorist danger in the region. Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov is speaking. “Russia has consistently advocated building up international cooperation to [head off] terrorism in any form,” he says. Cameron is done speaking. One passage to highlight: new powers he described that he said would help fight the terror threat. Cameron called for enabling “our police and security services to apply for stronger locational constraints for those who remain within the UK but who pose a risk”: “For our part in the United Kingdom, we’re introducing new powers to strengthen our ability to seize passports and stop suspects from traveling, to allow us to temporarily some British nationals getting back in the country; to ensure that airlines comply with no-fly lists and security screening arrangements; and to enable our police and security services to apply for stronger locational constraints for those who remain within the UK but who pose a risk.” “The United Kingdom is committed to meeting this challenge,” Cameron says. “... “We need to act, and we need to act now.” The British prime minister says “one of the most disturbing aspects of the conflict” is how it is “sucking in young people”. He says “in my own country,” 500 “of these fanatics have gone to Syria and Iraq.” British people are sickened that a British citizen could be involved in murdering people, including a fellow British citizen, who had gone to Syria to help people. THere are no easy answers or quick fixes, and I believe we’ll be dealing with this threat for years.” Cameron is speaking at the security council. He says the conflict in Iraq “is shocking the world with its cruelty and barbarity.” Many fascinating lines coming out with the interview with the Iranian president happening in New York now: Update: Jordan’s King Abdullah addresses the security council: “First let me thank President Obama for his leadership on this issue, and Jordan can be counted on to play our part.” As our live blog coverage continues, here’s a summary of where things stand: The United Nations security council unanimously adopted a resolution to crack down on flows of “foreign terrorist fighters”. Under Resolution 2178, “nations are required to prevent and suppress the recruiting, organizing, transporting or equipping of foreign terrorist fighters, as well as the financing of their travel or activities,” said US President Barack Obama, who is chairing the security council session which is ongoing. The British parliament was recalled for a meeting Friday to discuss participating in air strikes against Isis militants in Iraq (but not Syria). Earlier Wednesday, Obama vowed to defeat Isis in a speech before the general assembly, calling on the world to “join the effort” to “dismantle this network of death.” Iraqi prime minister Haider al-Abadi met with Obama and asked for weapons, saying the Iraqi army had lost many of its weapons to Isis. Around 200 Iraqi soldiers were said to be trapped by Isis fighters in an army camp south of Ramadi in western Iraq. Isis militants killed at least 19 members of a Shia militia in an ambush attack outside Baghdad, Iraqi police said. An Algerian group claiming ties to Isis beheaded a French hostage, a tourist who was captured Sunday. Read the previous blog summary. As the UN security council meeting continues, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani is condemning US sanctions on Iran in an address sponsored by the New America Foundation: The US Treasury Department on Wednesday imposed sanctions on eight people it says have helped finance or facilitated the movement of foreign fighters joining the Islamic State and the Nusra Front, the Associated Press reports: Those are two Syrian extremist groups that have been the subject of recent American military strikes. The individuals were designated global terrorists, an action that cuts them off from the U.S. banking system and freezes any assets that may have in the U.S. The department also sanctioned three individuals and a charity accused of supporting a southeast Asian al-Qaida affiliate (Jemaah Islamiya) that is accused of bombing a Bali nightclub in 2002, killing more than 200. A White House pool report notes that Resolution 2178 passed the security council unanimously. For the authoritative account of how the resolution evolved – and how the United States decided to use the opportunity of Obama’s chairing the security council to focus on the foreign fighters question – read Hayes Brown at Think Progress, How Obama Decided To Make Terrorist Recruitment His U.N. Priority US ambassador to the UN Samantha Power says there are more than 100 co-sponsors of UN Resolution 2178. Obama describes one threat from foreign fighters: “Terrorists crossing borders and unleashing terrible violence.” Obama returns to his role as chair of the meeting, having just spoken as president of the United States. Obama: The historic resolution we just adopted enshrines our commitment to meet this challenge. It is legally binding. It establishes new obligations that nations must meet. Specifically, nations are required to prevent and suppress the recruiting, organizing, transporting or equipping of foreign terrorist fighters, as well as the financing of their travel or activities. Nations must prevent the movement of terrorists or terrorist groups through their territory, and ensure that domestic laws allow for the prosecution of those who attempt to do so. The resolution... calls upon nations to help build the capacity of states on the front lines of this fight, including with the best practices that many of our nations have approved yesterday... This resolution will strengthen cooperation between nations, including sharing more information about the travel and activities of foreign terrorist fighters. And it makes clear that respecting human rights, fundamental freedoms, and the rule of law is not optional, it is an essential part of successful counter-terrorism efforts. Finally this resolution recognizes that there is no military solution to the problem of misguided individuals seeking to join terrorist organizations. The US ambassador to the UN says the “opening business” included passage of a resolution setting new global rules to crack down on the flow of foreign fighters to conflict zones. “I welcome the council resolution just adopted,” Ban says. Resolution 2718 includes an unprecedented series of travel bans on so-called foreign fighters. The Guardian’s Dan Roberts reports: The need to prevent a Russian veto of the travel ban has also led to it being very loosely drafted – potentially designated as terrorist anyone travelling to a conflict zone – something that may alarm more liberal-minded members of the security council. Ban calls “groups like Isil or Daesh” the enemies of faith. “They should more fittingly be called the Un-Islamic Non-State,” he says. Obama dispatches with some opening business and turns the floor over to UN secretary-general Ban Ki-moon. Ban thanks Obama: “This is the second time that you have presided over this council” at a grave time. Obama is chairing the security council meeting. Here’s a live stream: A 19-year-old from Brighton is believed to be among those killed in Syria in the past 48 hours, the Guardian has learned: Two western fighters in Syria said Khalil al-Britani, whose real name is understood to be Ibrahim Kamara, died after a US air strike on Aleppo. Kamara was described as being a member of Jabhat al-Nusra, an affiliate group of al-Qaida which has fought against both the forces of the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, and Islamic State militants in the country’s civil war. A picture posted on Facebook on Tuesday night appears to show Kamara’s face in an unzipped body bag covered in fine sand. The Guardian has not been able to independently verify whether Kamara was killed by a US air strike. [...] His mother, Khadijah Kamara, 35, who lives in Brighton, told the Guardian that she felt numb and confused when she was told on Tuesday that her son was dead. “It’s confusing. I don’t know what I felt or how I am feeling.” Read the full piece here. After the general assembly this morning and his meeting with the Iraqi prime minister, it’s lunchtime for US President Barack Obama, according to a White House pool report: Obama is having lunch with leaders in the delegates room, a long hall lined with flags on one end and tapestries on the other. [...] Obama rose and cracked a joke about the terrible traffic in New York during the UN general assembly. As someone who lived in New York, he knows first hand “It is no fun.” In 2008, when he was a senator with Secret Service protection, he even got stuck in the congestion. “I still couldn’t get through the traffic and had to walk three blocks.” A note about the president’s speech this morning: A White House official said Obama wrote most of the address, with an assist from Ben Rhodes. The official said the president had included the Ferguson section to acknowledge, in a speech with sharp criticism of divisions in other nations, “that we’re not perfect.” The Pentagon said earlier Wednesday that one airstrike had “damaged eight ISIL vehicles in Syria northwest of Al Qa’im.” Earlier we published one picture believed to be of the strike. Here are others: Barack Obama has called for a meeting of regional powerbrokers in the Middle East to negotiate a broader political solution to current instability, in a potential glimpse into longer term US strategy for resolving the civil wars in Syria and Iraq, Guardian Washington bureau chief Dan Roberts (@RobertsDan) reports: Speaking before the United Nations general assembly, the president said it was “time for a broader negotiation in which major powers address their differences directly, honestly, and peacefully across the table from one another, rather than through gun-wielding proxies”. Pressure is growing in Washington for Obama to explain how recent US strikes against Islamic extremists in Syria and Iraq will bring about a more lasting political settlement and his comments may indicate an eventual willingness to negotiate with Shia leaders in Iran over their involvement in both countries. In thinly-veiled criticism of Gulf states who the US believes allow funds to flow to Islamic extremists and hardline religious schools across the Middle East, the president said there would be no lasting peace until such radicalism was checked at its root. “It is time for a new compact among the civilised peoples of this world to eradicate war at its most fundamental source: the corruption of young minds by violent ideology,” said Obama. Read the full piece here. The White House has issued a transcript of statements by US President Barack Obama and Iraqi Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi following their bilateral meeting at the UN today. Abadi said in part that he has asked Obama for weapons and had “emphasized the importance of the respect of the sovereignty of Iraq and the territorial integrity of Iraq”. Abadi’s comment includes the admission that the Iraqi military lost a lot of weapons to Isis, Guardian Washington bureau chief Dan Roberts (@RobertsDan) points out. Here’s a snippet of Abadi: In my discussion with President Obama, I emphasized the importance of the respect of the sovereignty of Iraq and the territorial integrity of Iraq. And as a Prime Minister of Iraq, I reaffirmed the importance for all forces that want to help Iraq to respect the sovereignty of Iraq and its territorial integrity. I am very thankful for President Obama and all the allies, all who are helping, for maintaining and respecting the territorial integrity of Iraq and its sovereignty. Finally, one of the requests that I have put forth for President Obama is the importance of equipping and arming the Iraqi army and to provide the Iraqi armed forces with weapons. As you know, our armed forces are in dire need for equipment and for weapons, mostly because we lost a lot of the equipment and the weapons in our confrontation and our fight against ISIL, and specifically when the ISIL groups came through the borders from Syria, many of the weapons were destroyed. Some of the weapons fell in the hand of ISIL. Therefore, I am very thankful for President Obama that he promised that weapons and supplies would be delivered to Iraq as soon as possible so Iraq can defeat ISIL and Iraq can overcome this crisis. The Dutch government says it will send six F-16 fighter jets to strike at the Islamic State extremist group in Iraq, the Associated Press reports: Deputy Prime Lodewijk Asscher said Wednesday the Cabinet will deploy the six planes and two reserve jets along with 250 pilots and support staff. The Dutch also will send about 130 military trainers to Iraq to support Iraqi and Kurdish fighters battling the Islamic State group on the ground. Asscher said the Dutch government doesn’t currently see an international mandate for joining airstrikes in Syria. Defense Minister Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert said the Dutch jets will likely be based in Jordan. French President François Hollande has confirmed the killing of Hervé Gourdel in Algeria and said the act strengthened his determination to “fight terrorists everywhere”: “Our compatriot has been murdered cruelly and in a cowardly way by a terrorist group,” Hollande told reporters ahead of his speech to the U.N. General Assembly in New York. “Hervé Gourdel was killed because he was French.” “My determination is total and this aggression only strengthens it,” he said. “France will continue to fight terrorists everywhere. The operations against Islamic State will continue. The military air strikes will continue as long as necessary.” Further Hollande remarks via AP: “I am speaking to you with a particularly high level of emotion,” Hollande said. “This particular group ... they don’t strike only those who don’t think like they do, they also strike Muslims ... they rape, they kill,” Hollande added. “It is for this reason that the fight the international community needs to wage versus terrorism knows no borders.” Guardian political editor Patrick Wintour (@patrickwintour) has filed a lengthier take on the news of parliament’s recall. British aircraft could see action as early as this weekend, he reports: Parliament is to be recalled on Friday to endorse British air strikes in Iraq following assurances from the leader of the opposition, Ed Miliband, to the prime minister, David Cameron, that his party will support UK involvement in the country. Britain is likely to send RAF Tornado aircraft into action, possibly as early as this weekend, once MPs have voted. [...] Parliament will not debate any UK action in Syria at this stage, after Labour indicated it would not support UK involvement there without a UN resolution to authorise action in a country where military help to fight Isis has not been requested. At the close of the Labour party conference in Manchester, Miliband convened an emergency meeting of the shadow cabinet to endorse military action in Iraq so providing Cameron the assurance he needed that he would win the Commons vote.[...] Read the full piece here. Around 200 Iraqi soldiers were trapped in an army camp in western Iraq on Wednesday, Reuters reports, besieged by Islamic State militants who routed hapless army forces in a raid on a base close to Baghdad at the weekend: A soldier cornered in the camp said food, weapons and ammunition were running short, with forces sent to rescue them struggling to clear a route. “There are troops behind us but they can’t reach us because the whole area is planted with roadside bombs and land mines,” said Hussein Thamir, a soldier who spoke to Reuters from inside the Albu Etha camp, about 10 km south of the city of Ramadi. “There was an army group in front of us whom (Islamic State) destroyed completely six days ago,” said Thamir. “If we withdraw, will be killed.” Using similar tactics, Islamic State insurgents on Sunday overran an army base in Saqlawiya, just 50 km (30 miles) west of Baghdad, killing or capturing between 400 to 600 soldiers, a senior Iraqi security official said. The heavy losses revealed once again the parlous state of the Iraqi army, which is riven by endemic corruption and low morale, and which crumpled this summer as Islamic State took control of roughly a third of the country. Read the full piece here. Britian’s parliament is to be recalled on Friday to endorse air strikes in Iraq as early as this weekend, “following assurances from Labour party leader Ed Miliband to Prime Minister David Cameron that he will support UK involvement in the country,” writes Guardian political editor Patrick Wintour (@patrickwintour). “Britain is likely to send RAF Tomahawk aircraft into action.” In a short statement, a spokesman for Cameron said: “The Speaker has agreed to the Prime Minister’s request to recall Parliament this Friday to debate the UK’s response to the request from the Iraqi Government for air strikes to support operations against ISIL in Iraq. “The Commons will meet on Friday for a debate on a substantive motion. The Prime Minister will open the debate and the Deputy Prime Minister will close the debate. The Prime Minister has called a meeting of the Cabinet tomorrow at 1pm.” Patrick adds: At the close of the Labour party conference in Manchester, Miliband had convened an emergency meeting of Labour’s cabinet to endorse military action in Iraq so providing Cameron the assurance he needed that he will win the vote in parliament. The path was also cleared after Cameron met Iraqi prime minister Haider al-Abadi in New York to receive a formal request for military action, so clearing a vital legal hurdle to UK involvement. The Iraqi government has requested that Britain carry out air strikes against Isis militants, the Press Association quotes Cameron as saying. The speaker has accepted Cameron’s request; parliament has been recalled. Cameron asks MPs to convene on Friday. The Press Association in London reports that prime minister David Cameron has requested the recall of parliament to debate the UK’s response to the Iraqi government’s request for support against Islamic State militants. A Kurdish organization has accused the Turkish government of backing Islamic State militants fighting against Kurdish forces in Syria, AP reports: The statement was issued Wednesday by the Kurdish Communities Union, whose honorary leader is Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned leader of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, the Kurdish rebel group that has long fought Turkey for autonomy. The umbrella group accused Turkey of “waging a war against the Kurdish people” and vowed to step up its “struggle.” It accused Turkey of supporting Islamic State group battling Syrian Kurdish forces along the Syria-Turkish border, and of stalling the peace process that it launched two years ago with the Kurdistan Workers’ Party that led to the cease-fire in Turkey. In New York on Tuesday, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan promised support for the US strikes against Isis militants in Syria. Isis militants killed 19 Shia militiamen in an ambush north of Baghdad on Wednesday, officials said, the Associated Press reports: Police officials said fighters from the Islamic State extremist group hiding in orchards opened fire with machine-guns on a convoy of Shiite militiamen travelling on a road in Babilan village. They said 39 other people were wounded in the attack. Babilan is about 90 kilometers (60 miles) north of Baghdad. In other violence, police said three separate bombings in commercial areas of the capital killed seven people and wounded dozens of others. Read the full report here. The Pentagon on Wednesday said it was still investigating whether US strikes in Syria on Tuesday killed a leader of the al Qaeda-linked Khorasan group, adding that it could take time to determine, Reuters reports: “We just don’t have a confirmation to make at this point,” said Pentagon spokesman Colonel Steve Warren. “We don’t have personnel on the ground to verify, so we’re continuing to assess.” Reuters quoted a U.S. official earlier on Wednesday saying the United States believed one of those killed in the strike against the group was Mohsin al-Fadhli, who the U.S. government has identified as a al Qaeda financier close to al Qaeda founder Osama bin Laden. Saudi pilots who conducted air strikes on jihadis in Syria have received online death threats after photos were published of those involved, among them a son of the crown prince, AFP reports: Saudi Press Agency (SPA) released photographs of eight airmen it said were involved in Tuesday’s US-led operation, carried out with Gulf allies. In one picture they stood, some smiling, in green flight suits with arms around each other in front of one of their fighter jets. One of the pilots involved in the raids is a son of Crown Prince Salman bin Abdul Aziz, according to Saudi newspapers. Read the full report here. As our live blog coverage continues, here’s a summary of where things stand: In an address before the UN general assembly, President Barack Obama called on the world to help defeat Isis and what he called its “network of death” in Iraq and Syria. Obama said the only language the extremists understood was one of force and that the United States would fight until they were defeated. Obama’s speech included sharp criticism of Russia, which he accused of violating Ukraine’s sovereignty and promoting “might makes right.” “America stands for something different,” Obama claimed. “We believe that right makes might.” Read Julian Borger’s report on Obama’s UN speech, “Obama vows to defeat Isis and rallies world’s nations to ‘join in this effort’” The Pentagon described five new air strikes against Isis in Syria. “There’s definitely a second day and there’ll be a third and a fourth” in Syria, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry told CNN. It appeared that UK prime minister David Cameron might request a recall of parliament Friday for a vote on Britain joining the war effort. Labor was meeting to discuss the move. An Algerian group claiming ties to Isis beheaded a French hostage, a tourist who was captured Sunday. The family of British hostage Alan Henning has expressed concern that air strikes in Syria would complicate the effort to win his release. Read the previous blog summary Algerian jihadis linked to Isis militants in Iraq and Syria have beheaded a French tourist they have been holding since the weekend, Kim Willsher (@kimwillsher1) reports from Paris: The group calling itself Jund al-Khilafah – or Soldiers of the Caliphate – released a video showing the beheading of mountain guide Hervé Gourdel, according to the US terrorism watchdog, Site. The video was entitled Message in Blood for the French Government. Gourdel, 55, from Nice, was abducted on Sunday while on holiday in Algeria. The kidnappers had threatened to kill him within 48 hours unless France halted air strikes on Isis territory. Read the full report here. The family of Alan Henning, the British aid worker currently held by Isis militants, fears that US-led air strikes in Syria will damage the cause of securing Henning’s safe return. “They’ll just run away and take him with them, and no one will know where he is again,” said brother-in-law Colin Livesey. “They might have a fair idea of where he is right now.” Read more about Henning here. The Guardian’s Constanze Letsch (@constanzeletsch) has visited the Turkish border town of Akçakale, which sits meters from the Syrian town of Tel Abyad, now occupied by Isis. “At least they are quiet,” [a resident] says. “The FSA used to shoot in the air all the time. These guys don’t make a racket all the time. These are small mercies. But we are worried about the bombing by the Americans. When has that ever done any good?” Constanze has filed this portrait of the mood in the town, including robust disapproval for US air strikes: Abdullatif Ismail, 50, used to work with the Syrian secret police in Raqqa, but says he defected when the government openly started killing people. He came to Turkey a year and nine months ago. His wife and two daughters live with him in a rental flat in Akçakale; he works as a volunteer teacher in a refugee school nearby. His son works in Saudi Arabia; his mother and extended family have stayed in Raqqa. Every day they exchange news using the WhatsApp message service . “I heard about the air strikes in Raqqa,” he says. “Air strikes are not a very precise method. Raqqa is a big city, many people live there who are not Isis.” Here is further detail on the threats against German hostages in the Philippines (see earlier report here). “Islamists in the Philippines have threatened to kill two German hostages unless Germany pays a ransom and withdraws its support for the US fight against Isis in Syria and northern Iraq,” the Guardian’s Philip Oltermann (@philipoltermann) writes from Berlin: In a message circulated via Twitter, the Abu Sayyaf terrorist group announced it would “kill one of the hostages” unless its demands were met within 15 days, according to US company Site Intelligence Group, which tracks communications from radical Islamist groups. The message calls on Germany to “stop supporting America in its killing of our Muslim brothers in Iraq and Syria, especially the mujahideen of the Islamic State”. The German pair, 71-year-old Stefan O and 55-year-old Henrike D, were reported missing in April, after their yacht was found empty in the Palavan province in the western Philippines. Read the full piece here. Guardian diplomatic editor Julian Borger (@julianborger) has written a background piece with some of the history and highlights of the UN general assembly, in which more than 140 world leaders converge on the UN headquarters at Turtle Bay in midtown Manhattan to discuss some of the many urgent matters of the day: Each head of state or government will have 15 minutes to say what is on his or her mind at the assembly’s famous green marble podium. It is a restriction often abused, though seldom as much as by Muammar Gaddafi in 2009 when he spoke for more than 90 minutes. For colorful details of life inside the UN chamber, including the factoid that “Smoking is now prohibited in the chamber and the ashtrays have been removed from the delegates’ desks, one of the first changes to the 1940s design,” read the full piece here. And check out this video of the UN general assembly’s greatest hits: Cameron and Rouhani meet. The Guardian’s Saeed Kamali Dehghan has filed a report exploring the tricky balance Rouhani must strike while in New York to avoid offending potential critics on all sides: Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, has to weigh up every step he takes as he visits the UN in New York, accommodating world leaders while not upsetting hardliners at home. Wednesday’s meeting with the British prime minister, David Cameron, the first such encounter in decades, just adds to the complications. In Tehran, domestic repercussions of any potential statements he will make or meetings he will attend, can be costly. Hawks and fundamentalists, such as those in the Iranian parliament, will be circling like vultures to watch him slip. Last year in New York, the 65-year-old made a difficult choice and despite his own willingness decided not to commit to a historic handshake in the corridors of the UN headquarters with the US president, Barack Obama. Read the full piece here. Guardian political editor Patrick Wintour (@patrickwintour) reports that the shadow cabinet was meeting in an unexpected emergency session in Manchester, where the opposition Labour party is having its annual conference, to discuss whether to support air strikes in Iraq “in light of notification from Downing Street that it would like to recall parliament later this week”: The recall will not go ahead unless and until Labour makes clear it will support air strikes in Iraq. Labour has said it supports the air strikes undertake in Syria by America so far, but it has called for a UN Security Council resolution before strikes inside Syria. Shadow Cabinet sources said the meeting is likely to focus on whether to support air strikes in Syria at this stage given the doubts about its legality, and the absence of a viable ground force inside Syria that can combat IS, but does not lead to a strengthening of President Assad. “If the shadow cabinet agrees to support UK involvement in the air strikes in Iraq, David Cameron will seek a recall of parliament,” Patrick writes. “Normally 48 hours is required for parliament to be recalled, but these rules can be waived.” You can read our further coverage of the question of whether parliament will be recalled here. Next for Obama: a meeting with the Iraqi prime minister, whose governments was one of the purported world bright spots singled out by the American leader: Yet, we also see signs that this tide could be reversed – a new, inclusive government in Baghdad; a new Iraqi Prime Minister welcomed by his neighbors; Lebanese factions rejecting those who try to provoke war. These steps must be followed by a broader truce. Some reactions from our correspondents: As our live blog coverage continues, here’s a summary of Obama’s speech: The president made a moral appeal to the world to join the fight against Isis militants and terrorism in general. Obama said “violent extremism” in the “Muslim world” was “one issue [that] risks a cycle of conflict that could derail” world progress. Obama delivered this jeremiad against Isis: “No God condones this terror. No grievance justifies these actions. There can be no reasoning – no negotiation – with this brand of evil. The only language understood by killers like this is the language of force. So the United States of America will work with a broad coalition to dismantle this network of death.” Obama expressed sharp criticism of Russia, accusing Moscow of promoting “a vision of the world in which might makes right – a world in which one nation’s borders can be redrawn by another, and civilized people are not allowed to recover the remains of their loved ones because of the truth that might be revealed.” Obama said Iran had an “historic opportunity” to cut a nuclear deal: “My message to Iran’s leaders and people is simple: do not let this opportunity pass.” Obama referred to the killing of Michael Brown: “I know the world also took notice of the small American city of Ferguson, Missouri – where a young man was killed, and a community was divided. So yes, we have our own racial and ethnic tensions.” Read the previous blog summary. The speech ran about a half hour. Obama concludes by saying “at this crossroads, I can promise you that the United States of America will not be distracted or deterred from what must be done.” He calls on the United Nations to “join us in this common mission, for today’s children and tomorrow’s.” That’s it. Applause. The US president glides into his peroration: After nearly six years as President, I believe that this promise can help light the world. Because I’ve seen a longing for positive change – for peace and freedom and opportunity – in the eyes of young people I’ve met around the globe. They remind me that no matter who you are, or where you come from, or what you look like, or what God you pray to, or who you love, there is something fundamental that we all share. Eleanor Roosevelt, a champion of the UN and America’s role in it, once asked, “Where, after all, do universal human rights begin? He also urged the west to tackle ideological and financial support for Isis in Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Turkey. Abdullah also stressed that the Syrian army was leading the fight against Isis on the ground in Syria. He said: “We are facing one enemy. We should cooperate. Abdullah said the current UN security council resolution on Syria was not enough to justify attacks on Syrian soil.
